Expectation1: Support each other emotionally during tough times
Situation1: One sibling has just received some very difficult news and is deeply distressed by it.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: Officials ask voters with last names A–M to move to a newly opened line, even though the original line is moving faster.
Story: I stood in the crowded community center, clutching my phone in one hand and my voter registration card in the other. My stepbrother had just called, his voice trembling as he told me about the news—our dad’s illness had taken a turn for the worse. He needed me, just to talk, to be there for him, like we always promised we would. But at that moment, an election official called out, “If your last name starts with A through M, please move to the new line on the left.” My last name was right in that range. The new line was barely moving, but the official’s voice was firm, and the sign clearly said to follow instructions. I could see people glancing at me, waiting for me to move. My phone buzzed again—my stepbrother, probably needing comfort. I felt torn, the weight of my promise to him pressing against the civic duty to follow the rules. My heart pounded as I stood frozen, caught between being the sibling he needed and the responsible voter I was supposed to be.
